user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(mut_prop);

    memset(mut_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_mut_sem_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_mutex_table, token);

        strncpy(mut_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(mut_prop->name) - 1);
        mut_prop->creator = record->creator;

        return_code = OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, mut_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_mut_sem_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_mutex_table
...
int32 OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop)
{
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other pointer uses in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they are intentionally non-const: - The function parameter OS_mut_sem_prop_t *mut_prop is an output/INOUT parameter (it is zeroed via memset and then populated), so it must be a non-const pointer. - The local variable token is passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById and OS_ObjectIdRelease, both of which modify the token, so a non-const pointer is required. - The implementation function OS_MutSemGetInfo_Impl already declares its first parameter as const (const OS_object_token_t *token), so that use follows the rule. - OS_ObjectIdGetById and OS_ObjectIdRelease operate on the token object (initialization/release) and therefore correctly take non-const pointers. The listed suspicious fragments are the remaining places where non-const pointers or pointer-to-non-const data are used for read-only access (accessing fields of the object table). These should be investigated to determine whether the referenced table/record should be pointed to via const-qualified pointer types (e.g. const OS_common_record_t *), or whether the data truly needs to remain mutable.
